channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Neighbors Cast Doubt on Elections That Gave Mnangagwa the Win
item.description: The main regional bloc in southern Africa and the African Union declined to rubber stamp the elections and cast doubt on a vote that led to President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s re-election.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Tendai Marima
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Campaign posters for President Emmerson Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe in Harare, the capital, on Sunday.

item.title: With Prigozhin Dead, Russia’s Wagner Faces an Uncertain Future
item.description: It could be hard for the Kremlin to find a way to neutralize the mercenary group after Yevgeny Prigozhin’s death while retaining its fighting power and geopolitical links.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Moscow paid their respects this weekend at a makeshift memorial for Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner mercenary group, and others killed last week.

item.title: Canada Revisits Ancient Prevention Tactics to Battle Wildfires
item.description: A movement to fight wildfires by making forests more resilient and, in some cases, deliberately setting blazes is gaining ground in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A slice of forest in British Columbia that was scorched by fire in 2021. A nearby section of forest was relatively unscathed after Indigenous fire prevention practices were applied there.

item.title: Russia Says Ukraine Fired Drones at Three Regions
item.description: The frequency of drone attacks inside Russia has increased in recent weeks, bringing the war to areas deep inside Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Soldiers with the 110th Separate Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled artillery gun at a Russian target in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Thailand’s Marijuana Business Is Growing Despite Regulatory Risks
item.description: The country’s legal marijuana business — a rarity in Asia — is struggling with oversupply, illegal imports and regulatory ambiguity. Investors are piling in anyway.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A cannabis farm in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand. The latest regulations for marijuana could give an edge to a high-quality domestic supply of weed.

item.title: U.S. Marines Killed in Air Crash in Australia
item.description: An Osprey aircraft with 23 people on board crashed during a joint training exercise near Darwin, in the north of Australia. Several others were seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Darren England/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A U.S. Marine MV-22B Osprey off the coast of Brisbane, Australia, in June. This was the type of aircraft that crashed on Sunday.

item.title: A Former French President Gives a Voice to Obstinate Russian Sympathies
item.description: Remarks by Nicolas Sarkozy have raised fears that Europe’s pro-Putin chorus may grow louder as Ukraine’s plodding counteroffensive puts pressure on Western resolve.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France arriving for a meeting on the Russian attack of Ukraine in Paris in February 2022.

item.title: Western Banks Help Fund Blacklisted Oligarch’s Charity
item.description: Konstantin Malofeyev’s foundation funds orphanages in occupied Ukraine. He denies that a child-removal program there is a war crime: “All of this is fake.”
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Konstantin Malofeyev at the International Russophile Movement congress in Moscow in March.

item.title: U.S. Knew Saudis Were Killing African Migrants but Kept Silent
item.description: The United States was told last year that Saudi security forces were shooting, shelling and abusing groups of migrants, but it chose not to raise the issue publicly.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Edward Wong
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ethiopian migrants on the outskirts of the Yemeni capital of Sana heading for the Saudi Arabian border, where some have faced violence at the hands of Saudi border guards.

item.title: At This Movie, Their Phones Won’t Bother You. Their Barking Might.
item.description: A cinema chain in Britain is welcoming dogs to select screenings. They don’t need their own tickets, and they don’t need to turn off their cellphones.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damian and Catriona Spandley, with their dogs Lucky and Jeff, attending a screening of the movie “Strays” at the Curzon Aldgate cinema in London on Saturday. Mr. Spandley is a Curzon employee.

item.title: FIFA Suspends Spanish Soccer Federation Chief Involved in Post-Game Kiss
item.description: The kiss and its aftermath have stirred debate over the treatment of women in Spanish soccer.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, the president of the Royal Spanish Football Federation, gave a defiant speech Friday in which he said he would not resign over the kiss he gave the Spanish player, Jennifer Hermoso.

item.title: New E.U. Climate Change Rules Anger Bloc’s Farmers
item.description: Asked to cut herds, move or even shut down to help meet E.U. environmental goals, agricultural workers say too much is demanded of them. Their anger is reshaping the political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Helma Breunissen at her farm in Renswoude, the Netherlands. She and other farmers bridle at being called peak emitters.

item.title: Egypt Demolishes Cultural Gems in Cairo in Push to Modernize
item.description: The Egyptian government has demolished historic tombs, cultural centers, artisan workshops and gardens in pursuit of large-scale urban renewal.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction of highways and roadworks in the Fustat area of Cairo this month.

item.title: How China’s Long Arm Nabbed the Dissident Lawyer Lu Siwei
item.description: Beijing has become more aggressive in its pursuit of dissidents overseas, as highlighted by the arrest of a Chinese rights lawyer in Laos.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Haiti Gang Shoots at Protesters, Killing Several in Port-au-Prince
item.description: The shooting reflects escalating tensions as vigilante groups push back against gangs in areas around Port-au-Prince.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: Relatives of people who were killed during a religious march in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Sunday.

item.title: Hailstorm in Germany Rips Through a Town, Damaging Buildings and Cars
item.description: An estimated 80 percent of buildings were damaged during a hailstorm in Bad Bayersoien, Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Remains of a marquee destroyed by a storm on the outskirts of Kissing, Germany, on Saturday.

item.title: Months After Earthquake, Syrians Feel Forgotten
item.description: In northwestern Syria, a devastating quake six months ago compounded the damage of years of civil war. U.S. lawmakers just visited for the first time in a decade.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Spanish Soccer Chief Finds His Defenders Backing Away
item.description: Luis Rubiales was widely condemned for kissing a player after the Spanish women’s team won the World Cup, but retained a few public supporters. Many now appear to be reconsidering.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: The president of the Spanish soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, right, embracing Rocio Galvez, a player on the national team. He kissed Jennifer Hermoso, left, on the lips.

item.title: U.S. Commerce Secretary Faces a Wide Range of Issues in China
item.description: The secretary said she planned to discuss U.S. technology controls, commercial disputes and opportunities for doing more business in her visits to Beijing and Shanghai this week.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo, U.S. secretary of commerce, center, will meet with Chinese officials during a trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

item.title: The Joys of Sketching Birds
item.description: Times readers were invited to share their drawings of the avian life around them. Here are more of our favorites.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: President Emmerson Mnangagwa Re-elected in Zimbabwe
item.description: President Emmerson Mnangagwa won another five-year term, but did so by intimidating voters and manipulating the campaign process, the opposition says.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
item.media:description: President Emmerson Mnangagwa at a campaign rally in Harare, Zimbabwe, this month. The country has a history of election irregularities.

item.title: Ukrainian Commander Urges More Defenses in the Northeast
item.description: In an apparent break with Pentagon advice, Oleksandr Syrsky, Ukraine’s top general in the east, called for “all measures” to defend an area where Russia was threatening to take more territory.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed tank on a street in Kupiansk, in northeastern Ukraine, this month. Russian forces have managed to push forward around the city in recent weeks.

item.title: The Wildfires Are Still Burning, but the Economic Toll Is Becoming Clearer
item.description: Little economic support is available to evacuees now out of work, insurance disputes loom and economic growth may be eroded.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: West Kelowna, British Columbia, has been hit by substantial losses from wildfires.

item.title: ‘He Has Blood on His Hands’
item.description: In a Ukraine village, there are no tears for Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the leader of the Wagner private militia, whose presumed death in a plane crash was reported this week.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A damaged bridge in Bohorodychne, Ukraine.

item.title: How a Judge’s Ruling on Torture Imperils a Guantánamo Prosecution Strategy
item.description: In dismissing a confession in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole, Col. Lanny J. Acosta Jr. has shaken a foundation of U.S. government cases at the post-9/11 court.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: A U.S. flag waves over the court compound at Guantánamo Bay as seen from inside an abandoned airstrip hangar. The judge found that the “clean team” interrogations could not undo the damage of C.I.A. torture.

item.title: In New York City, the Chances of Spotting a Rare Bird are on the Rise
item.description: Sharp-eyed birders might spot brown boobies, a tropical species once rare even in the Southern states. A flock of Canada geese might just include a pink-footed goose, too.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:description: A large flock of greater white-fronted geese. The birds typically nest in Greenland, but if you look closely at a flock of Canada geese in New York, you might spot one of these.

item.title: Ukraine Is Still Grappling With the Battlefield Prigozhin Left Behind
item.description: He shored up Russian forces at their most vulnerable and drew Ukraine into a costly fight for Bakhmut, giving Moscow time to build defenses that are slowing Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for Yevgeny V. Prigozhin in Saint Petersburg, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: Raimondo Heads to China to Both Promote Trade, and Restrict It
item.description: The commerce secretary’s trip may be the clearest demonstration yet of the balancing act the Biden administration is trying to pull off in its relations with China.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, is set to meet with high-level Chinese officials and representatives of American businesses in Beijing and Shanghai next week.

item.title: The Eternal Search for the ‘Nemesis Bird’
item.description: For every devoted birder, there is a bird that continues to elude sighting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Trezza
item.media:description: A male Congo peafowl, a “nemesis bird” that the world-class birder Peter Kaestner has sought for decades.

item.title: Russia Denies Killing Prigozhin, Calling the Idea Anti-Putin Propaganda
item.description: The Kremlin and its proxies rebuffed suggestions that it was responsible for destroying a plane that reportedly carried the chief of the Wagner mercenary group.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne, Valeriya Safronova and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A truck on Friday near the village of Kuzhenkino, Russia, carried part of the private jet that Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was reportedly traveling on when it crashed on Wednesday.

item.title: Isabel Crook, 107, Dies; Her Life in China Spanned a Century of Change
item.description: A noted educator and anthropologist, she spent almost her entire life in China, where she was a committed friend of the Communist government.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: With BRICS Invite, Iran Shrugs Off Outcast Status in the West
item.description: The invitation came after a tumultuous year of domestic unrest and economic gloom, and follows a pivot by the country toward Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran, front row, second from left, onstage in Johannesburg on Thursday with other leaders of BRICS countries.

item.title: Climate Risks Loom Over Panama Canal, a Vital Global Trade Link
item.description: Lack of rain and changing weather patterns are slowing the ship traffic that moves goods around the world.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Cargo ships waiting at the entrance of the Panama Canal on Wednesday.

item.title: Denmark Moves to Ban Quran Burnings After Muslim Outrage
item.description: Danish and Swedish authorities have struggled to balance free speech with growing anger that security officials say has elevated the risk of terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Martin Sylvest/Ritzau Scanpix Foto, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Denmark’s government presented a bill banning the burning of scriptures in Copenhagen on Friday. From left are Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen, Justice Minister Peter Hummelgaard and Deputy Prime Minister Jakob Ellemann-Jensen.

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a Mexican resort thriller, a British time-travel caper and a coming-of-age drama from Costa Rica.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish
item.media:description: Luis Gerardo Méndez in a scene from “Time Share,” directed by Sebastián Hofmann.

item.title: Greece Wildfires Result in Dozens of Arson Arrests
item.description: Firefighters are battling blazes near Athens and in a region where about 180,000 acres have burned, according to an E.U. official who called it a record.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A firefighting aircraft over Dadia forest in northern Greece.

item.title: An Orchestra’s ‘Ode to Joy’ Calls for Ukrainian Freedom
item.description: As war in Ukraine continues, so does the Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, with a version of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony tailored to the moment.
item.dc:creator: Ben Miller
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, which is in its second year of touring, performed at Schönhausen Palace on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Drone Strikes Against Russia Are a Message for Its Own People
item.description: U.S. officials say they expect Ukraine to continue its attacks because they send a strong message: Kyiv can still strike back.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russian police officers standing in front of a building that was reportedly damaged by a Ukrainian drone in Moscow last month.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy to Face Trial in France on Charges of Campaign Financing by Libya
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy of France is accused of receiving illegal funding for his 2007 election from the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, who led France from 2007 to 2012, faces accusations in several long-running legal cases.

item.title: Russia Pushes Long-Term Influence Operations Aimed at the U.S. and Europe
item.description: A newly declassified American intelligence analysis says Russian spy agencies are using influence laundering techniques to hide the Kremlin’s involvement in cultivating pro-Russia and anti-Ukraine messages.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The Kremlin is hoping to develop a network of young leaders who will support Russia or spread pro-Russia messages in their home countries, according to a U.S. intelligence analysis.

item.title: How an Aboriginal ‘Voice to Parliament’ Could Be Australia’s Brexit Moment
item.description: Longtime racial tensions are hindering a push to add an advisory body for Indigenous people’s issues to the Constitution, an Aboriginal activist says.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia walks with Aboriginal people at a festival in the Northern Territory last month. Soon the country will hold a referendum on a measure to give the nation’s Indigenous people more of a say in issues that affect them.

item.title: Heineken Sells Its Business in Russia for 1 Euro
item.description: After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, hundreds of Western companies announced they would quit operating in Russia. But actually selling their assets and withdrawing has taken time.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Granville
item.media:description: Cans and bottles of Heineken beer at a supermarket in Moscow.

item.title: With Yevgeny Prigozhin’s Death, Putin Projects a Message of Power
item.description: The Kremlin appears to be sending the signal that no degree of effectiveness can protect someone from punishment for disloyalty.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a ceremony on the anniversary of the Battle of Kursk on Wednesday. Mr. Putin has been eager to convey his dominance in the wake of the Wagner rebellion.

item.title: Spanish Soccer Chief Rubiales Refuses to Resign Over World Cup Kiss
item.description: The players demanded change after Luis Rubiales declined to quit over kissing Jennifer Hermoso, a member of the World Cup-winning team.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: After Luis Rubiales, head of the Royal Spanish Football Federation, said on Friday he would not resign, players on the Spanish team that won the Women’s World Cup last weekend said they would not take the field until he is gone.

item.title: Presumed Death of Wagner Leader Puts In Doubt Group’s Future in Africa
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of the Wagner paramilitary group, had visited the Central African Republic in the days before his jet crashed, a top adviser to the country’s president said.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wagner mercenaries guarding the president and other high-ranking attendees at a Labor Day event in Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic, in 2019.

item.title: Russia Says Ukraine Targeted Crimea With Dozens of Drones
item.description: The attacks came the day after Ukraine claimed that its special forces had staged a brief raid into the occupied Crimean Peninsula and fought with Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: London Zoo Weighs Its Animals. All 14,000 of Them.
item.description: It can’t be easy to weigh a meerkat, but boy, does it look like fun.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Frank the meerkat taking his turn on the scale.

item.title: Two Arrested After Crooked House Pub Fire
item.description: The Crooked House pub in England’s West Midlands went up in flames earlier this month. Two men have now been taken into custody on suspicion of arson.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The burned-out remains of the Crooked House pub near Dudley, England.

item.title: Seafood Is Safe After Fukushima Discharge, But Some Won’t Eat It
item.description: Sushi is among several shunned foods as Japan dumps treated radioactive water into the Pacific. Experts say the fear is irrational but understandable.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, John Yoon, Hisako Ueno and Olivia Wang
item.media:description: Vendors and customers at a wholesale fish market in Beijing on Thursday, when China banned all Japanese seafood imports.

item.title: Jair Candor Tracks Brazil’s Amazon Tribes From the Shadows
item.description: Jair Candor combs the forest for Indigenous people who want no contact with outsiders. The goal: to prove they exist so their land can be legally protected.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Candor is perhaps the most accomplished tracer of isolated tribes in Brazil. “My curiosity is great,” he said. “But the respect for their rights is greater.”

item.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin, Renegade Mercenary Chief Who Rattled Kremlin
item.description: A tycoon and a Putin ally, he built a paramilitary force that fought by Russia’s side even as he castigated its military leaders. He died at 62 in a plane crash, Russian authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video provided by Concord Press Service, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s information agency, showing him at a cemetery for Wagner fighters in Russia’s southern Krasnodar region in April.

item.title: The 1,300-Year Search for the Loch Ness Monster: A Timeline
item.description: An expedition to find the creature will take place this weekend in Scotland. Here’s a look at previous attempts.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Loch Ness in the 1960s. The biography of an Irish saint who visited Scotland in the sixth century includes the first known reference to the Loch Ness monster.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Believes Prigozhin Was Killed
item.description: Also, the tiny forests with big benefits.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Portraits of Russian mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin and Wagner group commander Dmitry Utkin at a memorial outside the local office of the Wagner private mercenary group in Novosibirsk, Russia.

item.title: Prigozhin Broke the First Rule in Russia: Don’t Defy Putin
item.description: The fate of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin is a reminder of all those who have paid a heavy price for standing up to President Vladimir V. Putin, and of how quickly people can fall from his favor.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin addressing the nation on June 26.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Ballot Delays Force Election Into 2nd Day
item.description: Other voters in Zimbabwe had to return the next day to vote for president, and the police raided election observers. The main candidates both predicted victory.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
item.media:description: A polling station in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Thursday. Most of the voting problems were in urban areas, where the opposition tends to be stronger.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Take Time to Confirm Prigozhin Was Killed in Plane Crash
item.description: The Wagner Group has not confirmed its leader’s death, nor has the Russian government.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Debris from a plane that crashed in the Tver region of Russia on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Staged a Brief Raid in Occupied Crimea
item.description: Taking back the peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, has remained a core part of the Ukrainian war effort.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Explosion Likely Downed Plane and Killed Prigozhin, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The officials stressed that multiple theories about what brought down a plane in Russia were still being explored. President Putin acknowledged the incident and spoke about Yevgeny Prigozhin in the past tense.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, Riley Mellen, Muyi Xiao and Robin Stein
item.media:description: Part of a crashed private jet near the village of Kuzhenkino, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: As Wildfires Spread, Anger Rises in Greece Over Government Response
item.description: Firefighters were battling scores of blazes nationwide, but the threat to a precious woodland north of the capital had some fearing a dystopian future.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Flames rising above Mount Parnitha in Athens early Thursday morning.

item.title: Pentagon Plans to Begin Training Ukrainian Pilots on F-16s in U.S.
item.description: The decision is a shift from last week, when a U.S. official said the pilots could be trained in the United States if European training programs reached capacity.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Fadel Senna/Agency French Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A U.S. Air Force mechanic working on an F-16 fighter jet in 2021. The Pentagon will begin training Ukrainian pilots on the planes in the United States as early as next month, according to a U.S. official.

item.title: When Sea Ice Retreated, Some Emperor Penguins Didn’t Breed
item.description: New research indicates that a majority of emperor penguins in a region of Antarctica lost their chicks.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Emperor penguins brooding on Snow Hill Island in Antarctica.

item.title: Ukraine Observes Another Independence Day as the War Rages On
item.description: On the second Independence Day since Russia’s full-scale invasion, the mood in Kyiv was subdued.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
